author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Biden Sends Dueling Messages on Afghanistan
description: The administration has sought to reassure Americans that it is ending “forever wars” while signaling to Afghans that the U.S. is not abandoning the beleaguered country.
content: WASHINGTON — To listen to the White House and Pentagon, the exit of the last American combat troops from Bagram Air Base is not the end of the mission in Afghanistan. At least that was the signal to the Afghans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: U.S. Added 850,000 Jobs in June, and Wages Rose
description: The resurgent economy delivered the strongest one-month employment gain since last summer, the latest promising signal about the recovery.
content: Anxieties over a lag in hiring lifted on Friday as the government reported that employers added 850,000 workers in June, the largest monthly gain since August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: ‘Our Menu Is Very Darwinian.’ Leading McDonald’s in 2021.
description: Chris Kempczinski faces pressure to raise wages, offer healthier choices and make McDonald’s more vocal politically. Meanwhile, business is booming.
content: As chief executive of McDonald’s, Chris Kempczinski occupies one of the most powerful posts in the corporate world. There are more than 39,000 McDonald’s restaurants in 120 countries, employing some two million people. Small changes at McDonald’s have vast ripple effects, affecting supply chains, wages and consumer behavior around the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Only the Incompetent Need Apply
description: On the right, actual expertise is disqualifying.
content: I wrote a few days ago about how ignorance — ignorance about history, about science, about economics and more — has become a core conservative value. This exaltation of ignorance naturally goes hand in hand with disdain for expertise: A vast majority of scientists may agree that greenhouse gas emissions are warming the planet, but hey, it’s all just a gigantic hoax.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
title: Proving Racist Intent: Democrats Face High New Bar in Opposing Voting Laws
description: Democrats and voting rights groups say they can no longer count on the federal courts, including the Supreme Court, to serve as a backstop for preventing racially discriminatory voting restrictions.
content: The 6-to-3 decision by the Supreme Court on Thursday that upheld voting restrictions in Arizona has effectively left voting rights advocates with a higher bar for bringing federal cases under the Voting Rights Act: proving discriminatory intent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Collapse Wasn’t First for Inspector Who Said Tower Seemed in ‘Good Shape’
description: The chief building official of Surfside, Fla., had worked in at least six South Florida cities. The collapse of a 13-story condo tower prompted a review of his work in at least one city.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — José L. Haar is still claustrophobic and suffers from chronic back pain, lingering effects from the hours he spent trapped under rubble between two dead brothers decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Isabelia Herrera
title: Taylor Swift Rejoins Her ‘Folklore’ Crew, and 8 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Brent Faiyaz featuring Drake, J. Balvin and Skrillex, Chicano Batman and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Can One Florida Man Wrest Control of the G.O.P. From Another?
description: Florida’s governor and the former president may be headed for a 2024 showdown.
content: Former President Donald Trump may be the Republican Party’s de facto leader, but Florida Governor Ron DeSantis is clearly its man of the moment. Increasingly, political watchers are wondering when this will become a problem for the ambitious Mr. DeSantis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sternbergh
title: When New York Was Ours Alone
description: The city was glorious without tourists. But that time must come to an end.
content: If you stayed in New York through the duration of the pandemic, you may remember the past year unfolding not in months but in chapters. There was the Incessant Sirens chapter. The Banging Pots and Pans Out the Window at 7 p.m. chapter. The Fireworks Every Night chapter. And, of course, the (sadly now ended) Strolling the Boulevard With a To-Go Cocktail chapter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: One Wedding Ceremony. Two Couples. Four ‘I Dos.’
description: The sisters Mary Wilt and Melinda Stone celebrated their happily-ever-afters together in Texas.
content: James Wilt, razor-sharp in a jet-black suit, stood between his two daughters: Melinda Stone on his left, beaming in a white, floor-length gown, and Mary Wilt to his right, in a sparkly knee-length dress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A Reigning Opera Composer Writes of Trauma and ‘Innocence’
description: Kaija Saariaho’s labyrinthine work, premiering in France after a pandemic delay, is the most anticipated new opera of the year.
content: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — Susanna Malkki wanted more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Why the Delta Variant Could End Australia’s Pursuit of ‘Covid Zero’
description: The country’s current outbreak bears a warning: Without much more widespread vaccinations, the usual tactics of lockdowns and blanket testing may no longer be enough.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — Three days after the emergence of a rare Covid-19 case in Sydney, around 40 friends gathered for a birthday party. Along with cake and laughter, there was a hidden threat: One of the guests had unknowingly crossed paths with that single Covid case, an airport driver who had caught the Delta variant from an American aircrew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Is ‘Lettuce Water’ Really the Sleep Aid of Your Dreams?
description: A TikTok trend says so, but experts aren’t so sure.
content: In a TikTok video from May, a 21-year-old woman in London shoves a clump of lettuce leaves into a Superman mug, steeps them in hot water (with a peppermint tea bag, for taste) and drinks it. “Update, I do feel slightly drowsy,” she records herself saying from a reclined position later on. “Another update, lettuce has crack because your sis is gone,” she adds again, looking like she’s on the verge of falling asleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘The Great Filter’ Review: Earth Men, Home Alone
description: Frank Winters’s play, about two astronauts in lockdown after a mission, uneasily grafts tropes borrowed from hard sci-fi and odd-couple comedy.
content: An “experiment that could forever revolutionize the way that humanity interacts with the cosmos.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: 10 Influences That Explain Why ‘Fear Street’ Seems Familiar
description: The Netflix horror epic might have you thinking about slasher movies, ’90s rock and Scooby-Doo all at once.
content: A killer is on the loose in the film trilogy “Fear Street.” But not only does this Netflix horror extravaganza leave a significant amount of blood in its wake, it also sprays the screen with a gusher of pop culture references.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: With Kuba Kings and Kehinde, a Painter Rises Above the Fray
description: In Kinshasa, art is everywhere. Hilary Balu finds his focus uncovering the West’s powerful influences on African life.
content: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — When the painter Hilary Balu was studying at the Academy of Fine Arts in Kinshasa, one of the most populous cities on the African continent, he learned about all the masters: Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci and so on, until his curriculum turned to royal portraiture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: At Sweetgreen, Seeing the Future of Work in a Desk Salad
description: A favorite lunchtime destination of many urban office workers weathered the pandemic thanks to its digital savvy. It’s confident more people will be returning to their offices soon.
content: What can office desk salads tell us about the state of the pandemic?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden thanks new citizens for choosing America at a White House naturalization ceremony.
description: The event was part of an effort by the federal government to swear in almost 10,000 new citizens in celebration of Fourth of July.
content: President Biden hosted an emotional naturalization ceremony Friday afternoon at the White House as part of a federal effort to swear in almost 10,000 new citizens in celebration of Independence Day — drawing sharp, but unspoken, contrasts with the policies of his predecessor, Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Watch These 11 Titles Before They Leave Netflix This Month
description: Plenty to catch up on before a slew of titles leave for U.S. viewers by the end of July. These are the ones most worth seeing.
content: Oscar winners and family favorites lead this month’s parade of titles departing from Netflix in the United States, along with an unnerving indie thriller, an immortal Australian franchise starter, a beloved ’90s rom-com and a controversial Stanley Kubrick classic. (Dates reflect the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly Sundberg
title: Some People Flip Real Estate. I Flip Men.
description: Give me a fixer-upper and I’ll turn him into someone desirable — for someone else.
content: I am a man flipper. I meet a man, fix him up and flip him to someone else. Unlike people who flip real estate — buying houses, renovating them and selling them for a tidy profit — I see no gain from this arrangement, only loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Neyer
title: With Baseball Stamps, It Ain’t Over Until the Rights Issues Clear
description: Yogi Berra is the first player in nine years to appear on a U.S.P.S. stamp. Despite many deserving candidates — including Henry Aaron — it could be a long wait before we see another.
content: When the Yogi Berra Museum & Learning Center opened on the campus of Montclair University in New Jersey in 1998, Berra was well aware of how unusual it was for him to be there to celebrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Coral Murphy Marcos
title: The pandemic forced millions of Americans to leave the work force earlier than planned.
description: Millions of Americans have decided to retire since the pandemic began, part of a surge in early exits from the work force. The trend, which has broad implications for the labor market, is a sign of how the pandemic has transformed the U.S. economic landscape.
content: Millions of Americans have decided to retire since the pandemic began, part of a surge in early exits from the work force. The trend, which has broad implications for the labor market, is a sign of how the pandemic has transformed the U.S. economic landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Hear Case on Government Aid to Religious Schools
description: The case, from Maine, will address questions left open in a decision last year requiring Montana to let religious schools take part in a scholarship program.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether Maine may exclude religious schools that offer sectarian education from a state tuition program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Military and V.A. Struggle With Vaccination Rates in Their Ranks
description: President Biden could legally require members of the military to get vaccinated, but so far he has declined to do so.
content: WASHINGTON — Denis McDonough, the secretary of veterans affairs, said this week that he was considering a move to compel workers at V.A. hospitals to get vaccinated, fearing that centers with low vaccination rates were risking the health of veterans seeking care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley
title: June Jobs Report Delivers Good News and Big Questions for Washington
description: Payrolls surged and wages climbed, both positives for President Biden and the Federal Reserve. But stagnant labor market participation highlights a key risk.
content: Employers are hiring and wages are rising but the number of people actively working or looking for jobs remains stagnant, a phenomenon that is making it difficult for the Federal Reserve and White House to determine how much the labor market has recovered and how long the U.S. economy will continue to need hefty support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do this Weekend
description: ‘Summer of Soul,’ butter mochi and dark rosés.
content: Welcome. It’s a holiday weekend in the United States, another milestone, where we might pause and consider where we were one year ago. What’s changed? Take a minute this weekend to consider where you were, what you were feeling, what was happening, last Fourth of July. It’s raining here in New York, good weather for reflecting. Whether you’re at home or away this weekend, here are some of our best ideas for how to pass the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Jacob’s Pillow Is Back, With a Tapping Tour of the Grounds
description: Rain interfered with Dorrance Dance’s evening program, but the ensemble’s matinee was a playful, inviting reintroduction to the festival.
content: BECKET, Mass. — Over the past year and a half, the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival has faced greater challenges than the weather. Last summer, for the first time in its then-88-year history, the festival was forced to cancel all performances in its bucolic home here in the Berkshires. Last November, with the pandemic still raging, one of the festival’s two theaters was destroyed in a fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Can Men Wear Shorts to the Office Now?
description: A reader wonders, after more than a year of widespread remote work, whether dress codes have changed.
content: Given the heat wave currently sweeping the United States; the fact that most of us have been stuck at home for 16 months; the reality that many offices are no longer requiring a suit-and-tie dress code; the influence of tech culture, where shorts, tees and Tevas are acceptable work wear; and the fact that the rise of gender fluidity is finally eroding many of our most stubborn fashion prejudices, this is an entirely understandable desire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton, Léontine Gallois and Aurelien Breeden
title: Fashion Retailers Face Inquiry Over Suspected Ties to Forced Labor in China
description: French prosecutors are investigating whether household names like Zara, Uniqlo and Skechers profited from exploiting Uyghurs in Xinjiang, China.
content: France’s antiterrorism prosecutor’s office has opened an investigation into four leading fashion retailers over suspicions that they benefited from and concealed “crimes against humanity” by using forced labor by Uyghurs in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Bezos’ Exit Is One of Many Among Amazon’s Top Ranks
description: An unusual number of vice presidents are leaving for prominent jobs at public companies or high-growth start-ups.
content: SEATTLE — When Andy Jassy is elevated to chief executive of Amazon on Monday, taking the reins from its founder, Jeff Bezos, it will be one of the most closely watched executive handoffs in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Richard Branson Will Try to Beat Jeff Bezos to Space With July 11 Flight
description: The Virgin Galactic founder hopes to edge out, by nine days, Blue Origin’s first flight with a crew aboard.
content: Seeking to upstage Jeff Bezos as the first rocket company owner to go to space, Richard Branson, the British billionaire who founded a galaxy of Virgin companies, announced on Thursday night that he would be a member of the crew on the next test flight of the Virgin Galactic space plane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Labour Holds On to U.K. Parliament Seat, Easing Pressure on Its Leader
description: The election this week of the sister of Jo Cox, a lawmaker who was killed in 2016, was seen as a victory for Labour’s leader in a region where Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s Conservatives had made big inroads.
content: LONDON — Britain’s opposition Labour Party on Friday scored an unexpected if narrow victory in a battle for an open Parliament seat that was widely seen as a critical test for the party’s leader, Keir Starmer, who has been under pressure for failing to revive the party’s fortunes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Quest to Help Diabetic Son Endures With a Different Kind of Giving
description: Sean Doherty set up a private equity-like fund with other parents four years ago. Some investments in research have worked. Some haven’t.
content: Like any parent of a sick child, Sean Doherty wanted to help his son, Finn, who has Type 1 diabetes. Unlike many parents, he had the professional and personal resources to actually make a difference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: In Boston, Art That Rises From the Deep
description: History meets flamboyant fantasy in the work of Firelei Báez, whose installation on the waterfront reasserts the importance of the Caribbean in world history.
content: BOSTON — The East Boston shipyard on the harbor hosts a mix of maritime ventures, from vessel repair to a robotics start-up for autonomous navigation. Since 2018, art has found a roost here as well, in the Watershed, the exhibition hall that the Institute of Contemporary Art opened in a former copper and sheet-metal factory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: The Battle for 1776
description: Plans for America’s 250th birthday in 2026 are getting underway. But can the spirit of 1776 survive the history wars of 2021?
content: It’s been a tough year for 1776.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: Finding a Home in This Overheated Market
description: Listings that seem to linger on the market sometimes can turn out to be diamonds in the rough.
content: Peggy Bellar, a real estate agent in the western Catskills hamlet of Margaretville, N.Y., recalls the languid days of two years ago, when houses sat on the market an average 200 days before they were sold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: No Ovens Here
description: These high-summer favorites won’t leave your kitchen feeling like a sauna.
content: Well, it’s been hot this week, to state the obvious, and scary-hot in some parts of the United States. So let’s just not turn on the oven at all. (It always seemed a cruel irony of summer that the best time of year to bake pies — my opinion — is also the worst time of year to heat the oven.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Love of the Game
description: It’s hot outside, but Brooke Husic and Adam Nicolle’s puzzle sizzles even more.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This may seem selfish, but when I took a step back to writing two columns per week for Wordplay, I did so strategically, and with my own solving interests at heart. Thursdays have always been my favorite solving day of the week, so that was a no-brainer, and I wanted at least one tough themeless to sink my teeth into each week. So I chose the Friday puzzle for my other column.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Immerwahr
title: The Strange, Sad Death of America’s Political Imagination
description: The U.S. used to be a country of invention and  change. Today, our politics are sclerotic, our civic culture is in crisis, and our dreams are small. What happened?
content: The world didn’t expect much from Edward Bellamy, a reclusive, tubercular writer who lived with his parents. Yet if he lived small, he dreamed big, and in 1888 he published a phenomenally successful utopian novel, “Looking Backward, 2000-1887.” It told of a man who fell asleep in 1887 and awoke in 2000 to electrified cities, music broadcasts and “credit cards.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Professional Rugby Player Spends Sundays
description: Game day or not, Nate Brakeley is committed to the sport. He’ll also fit in some sci-fi reading and downtime with his fiancée.
content: During the week, Nate Brakeley works as a data analyst. But on the weekends, he competes with Rugby United New York, the city’s first professional major league rugby franchise, now in its fourth season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Can Food Delivery Work for Everyone?
description: How restaurants and delivery apps like Uber Eats and DoorDash are thinking about post-pandemic home delivery.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Going to the Beach? Here’s How to Check if It’s Polluted
description: Friday: Heal the Bay’s annual beach report card is out. Here’s what to know. Also, the recall election now has a date.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: On the Beach, a ‘Surprise of a Lifetime’
description: Will Whiston proposed to Dr. Kerry Morrison at her family’s house on the beach in Connecticut two years ago, just after she had finished a 24-hour hospital shift.
content: A heart made of seashells or perhaps the candlelit path leading down to the beach might have suggested the kind of night Dr. Kerry Morrison was about to have on Christmas Eve 2018. But she thought it was  going to be simply another evening at her family’s house on the beach in Fairfield, Conn., where she was visiting for an annual holiday get-together.
source.name: The New York Times

title: More than 100,000 restaurants received relief grants, but 265,000 were turned away.
description: More than 370,000 restaurants applied for more than $75 billion in funding from the Restaurant Revitalization Fund, nearly three times what the program had available. Around 105,000 businesses were approved for grants, which averaged just over $272,000.
content: More than 370,000 restaurants applied for more than $75 billion in funding from the Restaurant Revitalization Fund, nearly three times what the program had available. Around 105,000 businesses were approved for grants, which averaged just over $272,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: After ‘F9,’ We Watched the Ninth Movies of Other Franchises. Oof.
description: There’s a reason most series don’t run so long. But amid the dreck (cough — “Jason Goes to Hell” — cough), we found a few that held up.
content: I’m not sure anyone imagined, when watching “The Fast and the Furious” in the summer of 2001, that a modest flick about street-racing car thieves in Southern California might one day yield eight sequels. It’s not so much that this material didn’t warrant a return trip as that almost no material gets returned to so many times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: A Delicate Decision: When to End Search for Any Florida Condo Survivors
description: The death toll rose to 22 after four more victims were found, including the 7-year-old daughter of a firefighter. No survivors have been discovered since the day the condo collapsed.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — Even as officials and rescue workers pledge hope, however slim, that life could be found within the voids of the rubble of the Champlain Towers South condominium complex near Miami, the language around the tragedy has subtly begun to shift into the past tense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Why Marijuana Can Disqualify a Runner From the Olympics
description: The World Anti-Doping Agency has said that marijuana “can be performance enhancing,” could pose risks to athletes and violates “the spirit of sport.”
content: The news that the American sprinting star Sha’Carri Richardson faced disqualification from the Olympics after testing positive for marijuana quickly drew an outsized reaction across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: U.S. Leaves Its Last Afghan Base, Effectively Ending Operations
description: With little fanfare, Bagram Air Base — once the military’s nerve center — was handed over to the Afghans, after nearly 20 years of waging war from the hub.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — American troops and their Western allies have departed the U.S. military base that coordinated the sprawling war in Afghanistan, officials said on Friday, effectively ending major U.S. military operations in the country after nearly two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: 125,000 Absentee Ballots Will Likely Decide New York’s Next Mayor
description: It’s a tight Democratic primary race between Eric Adams, Kathryn Garcia and Maya Wiley, and the winner will hinge on absentee ballots. Here’s what to know.
content: Fresh off a vote-counting debacle that caught national attention, the chaotic New York City Democratic mayoral primary is moving into a new phase: the wait for absentee ballots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: As Afghan Forces Crumble, an Air of Unreality Grips the Capital
description: With the Taliban advancing and U.S. troops leaving, President Ashraf Ghani and his aides have become increasingly insular, and Kabul is slipping into shock.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — With his military crumbling, President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan fired a crucial part of his command structure and brought in a new one. He created a nebulous “supreme state council,” announced months ago, that has hardly met. And as districts fall to the Taliban across the country, he has installed a giant picture of himself outside the airport’s domestic terminal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith, Sophie Kasakove, Emily Cochrane and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: The Miami-Dade mayor ordered the demolition of the remaining Surfside condo.
description: The known death toll at the Champlain Towers South site rose to 22.
content: The mayor of Miami-Dade County said on Friday that she had ordered the demolition of the still-standing portion of Champlain Towers South, a decision made a day after fears that the damaged structure could fall and disrupt rescue efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC Plus, failing to agree on oil production levels, will try again on Monday.
description: Oil officials failed for a second day on Friday to resolve a dispute over quotas that prevented OPEC, Russia and their allies from reaching an agreement on raising production.
content: Oil officials failed for a second day on Friday to resolve a dispute over quotas that prevented OPEC, Russia and their allies from reaching an agreement on raising production.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Outsider Finds Suspense in Hollywood
description: Catherine Steadman talks about her new novel, “The Disappearing Act,” and Michael Dobbs discusses “King Richard,” his new book about Watergate.
content: The actress and thriller writer Catherine Steadman visits the podcast this week to talk about “The Disappearing Act,” her new suspense novel about the absurdities of Hollywood. Steadman was drawn to the idea of setting a story during pilot season, when actors from all over the world descend on Los Angeles once a year and compete for lead roles in new TV series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Who Needs Practice? Not Alexander Bublik
description: The unseeded player representing Kazakhstan would rather hone his game during Wimbledon matches than overwork his shoulder with practice serves. Whatever works.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Grigor Dimitrov said he had come to Wimbledon, where he reached the semifinals in 2014, “with great hopes just to play some more matches just to get myself a little bit of a rhythm.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: These Superheroes Could Sharply Reduce Heat Deaths
description: At a time when climate change is making heat waves more frequent and more severe, trees are stationary superheroes: They can lower urban temperatures 10 lifesaving degrees, scientists say.
content: DES MOINES — The trees were supposed to stay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Tran Thien Khiem, 95, Dies; a Power in South Vietnam Before Its Fall
description: For six years he was the nation’s second in command, a master of political intrigue who had plotted and thwarted coups before fleeing the Communist victory in 1945.
content: Gen. Tran Thien Khiem, who was second in command to President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam during the last six years of the Vietnam War and fled to the United States shortly before the fall of Saigon to Communist forces in 1975, died on June 23 in Orange County, Calif. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Afghanistan, Jobs, Rosé: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: A Juneteenth Wedding for Two Community Activists
description: Whitney Jean and Troy Alim II fell in love after meeting at a voter-registration drive in Chicago about five years ago.
content: Troy Alim II didn’t mean to be rude when he interrupted a conversation Whitney Jean was having during a Chicago voter-registration drive in 2016. But when he overheard her asking why they weren’t reaching people in certain communities and how they might be able to fix it, he couldn’t resist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: How to Go From ‘Veep’ Scene-Stealer to Action-Movie Apprentice
description: After a turn on the HBO comedy, Sam Richardson now fights alongside Chris Pratt in “The Tomorrow War.” But big-screen heroism isn’t as easy as it looks.
content: The poster for the new Chris Pratt sci-fi movie “The Tomorrow War” may have you doing a double take: Hey, over Pratt’s muscled shoulder, isn’t that’s Richard Splett from “Veep” brandishing a machine gun?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Finally, Experts Break the Silence on J.&J. Boosters
description: For too long, those who got the one-dose vaccine were left in the dark.
content: Early last month, I got my third Covid vaccine shot. I now realize this was overkill and I’m fairly embarrassed about it, but at the time I felt like I was operating in an information vacuum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Amazon After Bezos
description: The founder of the e-commerce giant steps down as C.E.O. in two days. Then what?
content: Jeff Bezos founded Amazon 27 years ago. He steps down as C.E.O. two days from now. His successor, Andy Jassy, will take over the e-commerce giant on July 5.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: This Lawyer Loses Most of His Cases. And He’s Proud of It.
description: “The case is lost,” says U Khin Maung Zaw, a human rights lawyer in Myanmar who is representing Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, “but the cause is won.”
content: BANGKOK — During his decades as a lawyer in Myanmar, U Khin Maung Zaw has lost nearly all of his cases. It is a record that fills him with pride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: For This Spanish Provocateur, Each Performance Is About Survival
description: Angélica Liddell says she doesn’t care about looking good onstage. Instead, her visceral works give her catharsis that she says keeps her alive.
content: GHENT, Belgium — There is nothing in contemporary theater quite like an Angélica Liddell monologue. The Spanish director and performer, who has crafted her share of monumental productions over the past three decades, pushes herself to grating, visceral extremes onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: What Should Doctors Do When We Experience a Miracle?
description: As a critical-care doctor, I become nervous at the idea of miracles. Yet one of my patients survived Covid despite incredible odds.
content: It was just before dawn in the intensive care unit when something unexpected happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Can’t a Person Get a Little Privacy Around Here?
description: When it comes to work life, it’s not always your call what stays under wraps.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Hash Halper, Street Artist Who Adorned New York With Hearts, Dies at 41
description: He was something of a downtown folk hero, bringing positivity to a harsh city with his humble shards of chalk. But he harbored his own struggles.
content: Sometime around 2014, little hearts drawn in chalk mysteriously began appearing on the streets of downtown Manhattan. Some materialized in clusters on sidewalks, while others cascaded along blocks. The hearts inevitably faded away, but for New Yorkers who encountered them, they offered a respite from the harshness of city life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Juliet Macur
title: Sha’Carri Richardson, a Track Sensation, Tests Positive for Marijuana
description: Richardson, a gold-medal favorite in the women’s 100 meters, was suspended for a month, putting in doubt an appearance at the Tokyo Olympics.
content: The American sprinter Sha’Carri Richardson, who was set for a star turn at the Tokyo Olympics this month, could miss the Games after testing positive for marijuana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Africa’s Last Absolute Monarchy Convulsed by Mass Protests
description: Eswatini, the former Swaziland, has been ruled by high-living kings since its independence in 1968. Its impoverished citizens say they’ve had enough.
content: JOHANNESBURG — As Africa’s last absolute monarch, King Mswati III of Eswatini chooses his country’s prime minister and cabinet, and possesses the power to dissolve Parliament. His grip on the nation’s limited economic resources has underwritten a lavish lifestyle of luxury cars and palaces, and his children flaunt their opulent birthday parties on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: ‘The World Is Watching’: Britain Gambles on Reopening Despite the Delta Variant
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson seems convinced vaccines have broken the link between cases and hospitalizations. In a few weeks, we’ll know whether he’s right.
content: LONDON — A week from now, more than 60,000 soccer fans will pack Wembley Stadium in London for the European Championship final. British travelers with two vaccine shots will soon be welcomed back to Germany, which had banned them. And Prime Minister Boris Johnson said he was on track to lift most remaining coronavirus restrictions on July 19 — or, as the British press has dubbed it, “Freedom Day.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren
title: ‘We Should Celebrate’: In-Person Graduations Return to New York
description: After one of the most eventful school years they’ll ever experience, the class of 2021 celebrated their accomplishments in person and in style.
content: In the Bronx, a valedictorian at one high school stepped onto the stage to deliver her speech only months after her grandmother died of Covid-19. In Brooklyn, a high school hosted its celebration at Socceroof, an artificial turf field in Sunset Park that soon became crowded with students and family members. And at an elementary school in the Bronx, a group of pre-kindergarteners sang “This Little Light of Mine” as onlookers took countless photos.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jeff Tweedy
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jeff Tweedy. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jeff Tweedy. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Coronado
title: Here’s Why This Economic Recovery Is Putting 2009’s to Shame
description: Friday's jobs report, and a slew of other data, shows going big and going early works.
content: Early Friday, the government reported that the economy added 850,000 jobs last month — a welcome pickup from the slower pace of jobs growth over the past three months and a sign that overall economic growth is tracking stronger than in the first quarter of the year. We are still roughly seven million jobs down from prepandemic levels of employment, unemployment among Black and Hispanic workers remains distressingly high, and millions have yet to return to the labor force. But if policymakers hold steady, we are also on the verge of creating a foundation for a more inclusive, resilient recovery — much more robust than what we experienced after the Great Recession, despite having suffered a much bigger jobs hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: In ‘Luca,’ a Character’s Disability Doesn’t Define Him
description: Pixar’s latest film deftly features a character born without an arm. Here’s how a director of “Crip Camp” came to consult on the project.
content: In a small fishing boat on the sparkling Mediterranean, Alberto Scorfano’s eyes land on Massimo Marcovaldo’s right arm, which ends at his shoulder. Massimo catches him staring, and Alberto’s eyes bulge. Massimo glances down at his shirtsleeve, pinned up with a fish hook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: No Place to Go When You Need to Go? These New Yorkers Have Ideas
description: The pandemic ignited a conversation about the use of public space, but the city’s lack of public restrooms has led to long lines and some uncomfortable situations.
content: Kyle was jogging along the paths of East River Park one afternoon when he felt something shift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Manhattan Real Estate Finally Bounces Back to Normal
description: The volume of sales surges back to pre-pandemic levels, but prices are up just slightly.
content: As vaccination levels rise and businesses reopen, residential real estate has finally bounced back to where it was before Covid devastated New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: After a Nightmare Year, Election Officials Are Quitting
description: The draining work of 2020 has spurred resignations and retirements. In a recent survey, one in three officials said they felt unsafe in the jobs.
content: WASHINGTON — In November, Roxanna Moritz won her fourth term unopposed as the chief election officer in metro Davenport, Iowa, with more votes than any other candidate on the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Hwaida Saad
title: A New Investigator Targets Powerful Officials in Beirut Blast Probe
description: Judge Tariq Bitar is seeking to lift the immunity of prominent political and security figures as part of efforts to prosecute those responsible for the deadly explosion in Beirut’s port last summer.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The judge investigating last year’s huge explosion in the port of Beirut has moved to summon a range of powerful politicians and security officials for questioning as suspects, which could result in criminal charges against them related to the blast, the state-run National News Agency said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: With a Scalloped Skort, Ashleigh Barty Salutes a Big Anniversary
description: Barty, the top women’s seed at Wimbledon, asked her apparel sponsor to design an outfit that paid tribute to Evonne Goolagong Cawley, the first Indigenous Australian woman to win the tournament.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — As the top-seeded Ashleigh Barty looked forward to Wimbledon this year,  she also looked back half a century. To another Indigenous woman from Australia. To a groundbreaking Wimbledon title. And, ultimately, to a hemline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: Meet the Man Flipper
description: And: a double wedding in Texas.
content: Everyone loves a good renovation project. There are few things more satisfying than seeing a decrepit house transformed into a beacon of beauty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: Going the Distance With Ease
description: Meron Haile and James Miles, who met over Instagram and with the help of a friend, were married this year on the Juneteenth holiday.
content: Sliding into a stranger’s DMs wasn’t something James Miles had ever considered … until he spotted Meron Haile on a friend’s Instagram in December 2016. He then asked the mutual friend, Leah Ojesina, to vouch for him, which she did, telling Ms. Haile she thought they would be great together, or at least good friends, if nothing more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dawn MacKeen
title: Influencers Are Drinking Chlorophyll Water. But Why?
description: The claims are vast, from clearer skin to fresher breath. Yet experts say the science is shaky.
content: This story was originally published on Nov. 15, 2019 in Styles. It has been updated to reflect the latest developments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Denmark’s Secret: There Is No Secret
description: Sometimes, timing and talent and teaching converge. Sometimes there is a story to tell and a path others can follow. And sometimes there is not.
content: Jan Laursen was inside the Parken Stadium in Copenhagen on the afternoon Denmark lost to Belgium. The result, at the time, felt secondary. For most in the crowd, the game was a chance to show their affection not only for the absent Christian Eriksen, but for a team that had acted with such grace and courage even in the thick of primal horror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: A Pandemic Lifeline for Restaurants, Delivery Is ‘Here to Stay’
description: As in-person dining returns, home delivery is holding up. For restaurants, services like DoorDash and Uber Eats could become a permanent part of their business.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Last fall, as the weather cooled and coronavirus cases began to rise, May Seto, the owner of Grand Lake Kitchen in Oakland, refurbished a used pizza oven and started a takeout and delivery pizza business out of an extra kitchen where she had cooked for catering and private events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Alexander Hamilton and Post-Covid America
description: Working from home was an “infant industry”; so was early retirement.
content: In the spring of 2020, the U.S. economy went into what I described at the time as a “medically induced coma”: We shut down much of the economy in an attempt to limit the spread of the coronavirus. This was, in retrospect, a wise policy that should have been followed much more thoroughly. After all, by slowing the spread of the virus, we didn’t just avoid overwhelming the health care system; we also bought time for the development and dissemination of vaccines, so that tens of millions of Americans who would have been infected without the lockdowns ended up dodging the bullet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: A July Menu to Celebrate Summer’s Bounty
description: David Tanis looks to tomatoes, lamb and apricots to anchor the courses in his seasonal market menu.
content: Midsummer means the market is brimming with great produce. With such a colorful bounty of goods, we can settle into our summer cooking routines with tasty meals that are bright, casual and best enjoyed outdoors as much as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines and Reid J. Epstein
title: Trump Is Said to Have Called Arizona Official After Election Loss
description: Donald Trump tried to reach the top Republican in metropolitan Phoenix as his allies were trying to overturn the state’s 2020 results, according to the official, who said he did not pick up the calls.
content: President Donald J. Trump twice sought to talk on the phone with the Republican leader of Arizona’s most populous county last winter as the Trump campaign and its allies tried unsuccessfully to reverse Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s narrow victory in the state’s presidential contest, according to the Republican official and records obtained by The Arizona Republic, a Phoenix newspaper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Member of Greece’s Neo-Nazi Golden Dawn Arrested After 9 Months on the Run
description: Christos Pappas, the party’s deputy leader who was taken into custody in Athens, will join the rest of the party’s leadership in prison.
content: ATHENS — Greek authorities have arrested a convicted member of the neo-Nazi Golden Dawn party after nine months on the run, a government minister said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: After Sudden Defeat, Captured Ethiopian Soldiers Are Marched to Prison
description: The scale of the loss suffered by one of Africa’s most powerful armies was on vivid display on Friday as thousands of government troops were paraded through Mekelle, the regional capital of Tigray.
content: MEKELLE, Ethiopia — Thousands of Ethiopian prisoners of war were paraded through the regional capital of Tigray on Friday as jubilant crowds lined the streets to jeer the captives and cheer the Tigrayan forces who only days earlier had routed one of Africa’s most powerful armies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Biden names University of Pennsylvania president as ambassador to Germany.
description: Amy Gutmann, a political science professor, would be the first woman in that post. She also helped hire Biden to a lucrative university job after the Obama administration.
content: President Biden on Friday nominated Amy Gutmann, the president of the University of Pennsylvania, to serve as ambassador to Germany, giving a prominent post abroad to an academic leader who hired Mr. Biden for a lucrative university position after the Obama administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Teenager in ‘Slender Man’ Stabbing Is Ordered Released From Mental Hospital
description: Anissa Weier does not pose a threat to herself or others, a judge said, ruling in a case involving an attack on a 12-year-old by 12-year-old friends.
content: A Wisconsin judge on Thursday ordered a 19-year-old woman released from a psychiatric hospital where she has been held for more than three years for her role in the nearly fatal stabbing of a friend, a crime she said was carried out to gain the favor of a sinister fictional character called Slender Man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Biden endorses a major change in how the military handles sexual assault cases.
description: A growing movement supports independent investigations and prosecutions of sexual assault cases, outside of the military chain of command.
content: President Biden said Friday that he wanted the military to remove the investigation and prosecution of sexual assault cases from the control of commanders, a sea change for the military justice system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: F.D.A. Releases More of Johnson & Johnson’s Vaccine, but Baltimore Plant Remains Closed
description: The move brings the total number of Johnson & Johnson doses made at the troubled plant and cleared by the F.D.A. to roughly 40 million.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators on Friday cleared a batch of vaccine that could furnish up to 15 million doses of Johnson & Johnson’s one-shot coronavirus vaccine, deciding they can be safely distributed despite production failures at the factory that ruined 75 million other doses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith, Sophie Kasakove, Emily Cochrane, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Frances Robles
title: The 7-year-old daughter of a Miami firefighter is among the victims.
description: Rescue crews found the girl’s body while searching the wreckage of Champlain Towers South, officials said on Friday.
content: Rescue crews found the body of the 7-year-old daughter of a Miami firefighter while searching the wreckage of Champlain Towers South, officials said on Friday, when the known death toll rose, by four, to 22. As many as 126 people remain unaccounted for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Campaigns Keep Close Watch on Count That Will Decide N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race
description: The tallying of more than 125,000 absentee ballots will determine whether Eric Adams retains his lead in the Democratic primary.
content: In a bland, sprawling warehouse in Manhattan, election workers carefully inspected piles of absentee ballots on Friday, an exercise that might be described as tedious if it were not so important.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Sheet-Pan Chicken Recipe May Just Make You Forget About Grilling
description: Zucchini and basil lend big flavor to this savory, summery weeknight dinner.
content: There’s an unwritten rule that dictates if you’re cooking a celebratory dinner, for the Fourth of July or any other summer gathering, then grill you must.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: A Dynamic Duo, on and Off the Stage
description: Julie Benko needed a piano player to accompany her at a gig. She found one, along with a future husband, when she met Jason Yeager at a Starbucks in 2013.
content: It was through music, not movement, that Julie Benko and Jason Yeager first introduced themselves as a married couple to their 107 friends and family members. After their June 5 ceremony in New York’s Hudson Valley, the bride and groom performed “Always,” a song Ms. Benko wrote for Mr. Yeager in the first few months they were dating. They eventually made their way to the dance floor, once their band picked up the tune. But it was important, they said, to kick off the festivities with what first brought them together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Zoo Animals Are Getting Experimental Coronavirus Vaccines
description: Big cats, ferrets, apes and bears are benefiting from a gift of 11,000 doses, but vaccines for pets are not recommended.
content: The Oakland Zoo in California started this week with bears, mountain lions, tigers and ferrets, the first of about 100 animals that are set to receive an experimental vaccine against the coronavirus over the summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Sha’Carri Richardson and Her Now Uncertain Path to the Olympics
description: Richardson has a magnetic combination of speed and charisma. But her use of marijuana before an event has jeopardized her chance to compete in Tokyo.
content: When Sha’Carri Richardson starts talking, the declarations are grand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Criminal charges against the Trump Organization.
content: The Trump Organization, the family real estate business that catapulted Donald Trump to prominence, was charged Thursday with running a 15-year tax fraud scheme. The charges open up an aggressive new phase in a long-running criminal investigation into the former president and his company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: No Charges for Honolulu Police Officers Who Fatally Shot South African Man
description: The death of Lindani Myeni became a cause célèbre in South Africa, intensifying criticism there of racism in the United States and a feeling of solidarity with African Americans.
content: Three Honolulu police officers will not face criminal charges in the fatal shooting of a South African rugby player whose death became a cause célèbre in South Africa and intensified criticism there of police killings of Black people in the United States, prosecutors said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Australia’s Path Out of the Pandemic: Will It Make You Scream With Anger or Joy?
description: The prime minister has finally acknowledged that Australia will eventually have to learn to live with Covid.
content: Prime Minister Scott Morrison has finally outlined a Covid exit plan, which will include the end of lockdowns and travel restrictions for vaccinated Australians — but it’s not clear when.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Pilots Who Landed Boeing 737 in Waters Off Hawaii Are Rescued
description: The crew members of a cargo plane reported engine trouble early Friday morning, just before they made an emergency landing in the water.
content: Two pilots forced to land a Boeing 737 cargo plane in the ocean off Hawaii early on Friday morning were rescued by the U.S. Coast Guard, according to the federal officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astra Taylor
title: Make Americans’ Crushing Debt Disappear
description: The American dream used to be owning a home with a white picket fence, but now it is getting out of debt.
content: Formerly enslaved people called the phase that followed the Civil War, and their emancipation, Jubilee. In doing so, they at once communicated the joy of freedom and knowingly invoked the authority of the Bible: jubilee as an Old Testament law commanding the end of slavery, redistribution of land and forgiveness of debts. The prophetic term was another name for the period more commonly known as Reconstruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Claire Moses
title: And the Trumps Themselves?
description: The Trump Organization has been indicted.
content: Donald Trump’s company has long engaged in aggressive accounting maneuvers that involve classifying many of its executives’ personal expenses as business expenses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Olympics Allows Protests, but Not During Events or on Medals Stand
description: A policy change by the International Olympic Committee acknowledges an era of athlete activism but will attempt to keep some stages off limits.
content: The separation of sports and politics has long been one of the most carefully protected, and fiercely debated, values of the Olympic Games. Rules exist to police that divide, and athletes have been punished — and even ejected from the Games — for breaking them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: China Bolsters Its Nuclear Options With New Missile Silos in a Desert
description: Satellite images of construction could fuel the debate over American nuclear modernization and the future of arms control negotiations.
content: Researchers in the United States have identified the construction of 119 new intercontinental ballistic missile silos in a desert in northwestern China, indicating that the country is carrying out plans to strengthen its strategic nuclear capability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: For a Taste of Ancient Peruvian Cooking, Head to Vermont
description: Thousands of miles from its place of origin, pachamanca — a centuries-old form of underground cooking — gets a spotlight.
content: ANDOVER, Vt. — The scent of mint and smoke erupted from the pit in the earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Lisa Friedman
title: Lawmaker Threatens to Subpoena Exxon After Secret Video
description: The chairman of a powerful House subcommittee said he is seeking answers from Exxon and other oil and gas giants over their role in spreading disinformation on climate change.
content: The chairman of a House subcommittee is demanding that executives of Exxon Mobil Corp., Shell, Chevron and other major oil and gas companies testify before Congress about the industry’s decades-long effort to wage disinformation campaigns around climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: China opens an inquiry into Didi, two days after the ride-hailing app’s Wall Street debut.
description: The action, announced in a terse statement, comes amid a broader crackdown by Beijing against technology giants.
content: Two days into Didi’s life as a publicly traded company on Wall Street, China’s internet regulator said new user registrations on the Chinese ride-hailing platform would be suspended while the authorities conducted what they called a “cybersecurity review” of the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Belgium’s Golden Team Searches for a Silver Lining
description: A loss to Italy at Euro 2020 sent another star-studded Belgian team home empty-handed. But not before it offered a peek at its future.
content: Belgium’s players were still, their faces blank, as they heard the clock strike midnight. At the other end of the Allianz Arena in Munich, Italy’s players were being slowly consumed by their fans, released only once they had surrendered their white jerseys and their green training bibs and, in some cases, their muddied shorts for use as future sacraments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: Ballet Tech Names a New Artistic Director
description: Dionne Figgins will succeed Eliot Feld, the founder of the dance nonprofit and school.
content: Ballet Tech, the nonprofit group that has made ballet training accessible to thousands of promising New York schoolchildren, has a new leader. The organization announced on Friday that the dancer Dionne D. Figgins would succeed Eliot Feld, its founder, as artistic director in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Review: ‘The Watering Hole’ Can’t Quite Quench a Thirst
description: The collaborative project conceived by Lynn Nottage is too heterogeneous and muddled to rally around one clear theme or concept.
content: The day I went to the Signature Theater it was so hellishly hot out that it felt as if the air was clinging to my skin. So I stepped into the air-conditioned coolness of the Pershing Square Signature Center for “The Watering Hole,” a theatrical installation conceived and curated by the Pulitzer Prize-winner Lynn Nottage. What I’d hoped for was refreshment. What I left with was a thirst for a more memorable and neatly composed offering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest Week 4: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by July 9 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on July 20.
content: Welcome to Week Four of our 12th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Hurricane Elsa could complicate the Surfside rescue effort.
description: The storm’s path remains unclear, but it could hit Florida early next week if the forecast holds.
content: Tropical Storm Elsa became Hurricane Elsa on Friday morning as it moved along a path that could batter the Caribbean this weekend and hit Florida early next week, potentially complicating rescue work at the site of the collapsed Champlain Towers South condominium building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Is Biden Declaring ‘Independence From the Virus’ Too Soon?
description: Less than half the country is fully vaccinated against Covid-19, and the contagious Delta variant is spreading. Still, the White House has an “America’s Back Together” celebration planned for July 4.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s plan to celebrate “independence from the virus” on the Fourth of July is running into an unpleasant reality: Less than half the country is fully vaccinated against the coronavirus, and the highly contagious Delta variant is threatening new outbreaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Two Justices Say Supreme Court Should Reconsider Landmark Libel Decision
description: Justice Neil M. Gorsuch added his voice to that of Justice Clarence Thomas in questioning the longstanding standard for public officials set in New York Times v. Sullivan.
content: WASHINGTON — Two justices on Friday called for the Supreme Court to reconsider New York Times v. Sullivan, the landmark 1964 ruling interpreting the First Amendment to make it hard for public officials to prevail in libel suits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Johnson & Johnson says its vaccine protects against Delta, adding to the arsenal against the variant.
description: Johnson & Johnson said its Covid vaccine was effective against the highly contagious Delta variant, adding to the growing body of evidence that the most widely available Covid shots offer protection against its most dangerous variants.
content: Johnson & Johnson said its Covid vaccine was effective against the highly contagious Delta variant, adding to the growing body of evidence that the most widely available Covid shots offer protection against its most dangerous variants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Sotheby’s and Christie’s Reimagined Auctions Pay Off
description: Major auction houses are investing in digital and shaking up their sales categories and timings, in part to draw a global audience.
content: What was an evening event is now an afternoon one. Degas and van Gogh are now 20th-century Modernists. Six-figure prices are few and far between.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Her Book Described Bringing Bill Cosby to Justice. Then He Was Freed.
description: Months before Andrea Constand’s memoir about the Cosby case and its aftermath was set to be published, a Pennsylvania Court overturned his conviction for assaulting her and released him.
content: Andrea Constand was taking what she has described as a step toward healing: 16 years after naming Bill Cosby in a lawsuit as the man who had sexually assaulted her, and three years after he was convicted and sentenced to prison for the crime, she was ready to tell her story in a memoir that is due to be published in September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: M.L.B. Puts Dodgers’ Trevor Bauer on Leave Amid Sexual Assault Investigation
description: The seven-day administrative leave will keep Bauer from making his start on Sunday. He has denied the allegations against him.
content: Trevor Bauer, the Los Angeles Dodgers star pitcher under investigation by the authorities in Southern California after a woman accused him of sexual assault, was placed on short-term administrative leave Friday by Major League Baseball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien
title: Four people were killed in a fire at a quarantine hotel in Taiwan.
description: Some guests worried that leaving their rooms would violate Covid-19 rules. The blaze renewed debate over the use of hotels as quarantine facilities.
content: When the fire alarm went off at a hotel in central Taiwan on Wednesday evening, Chen Chien-kuang, a 59-year-old missionary, immediately thought of escaping. But he was one of 29 people in coronavirus quarantine inside the hotel and worried about breaking the rules, which required those in quarantine to stay inside their rooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: FEMA Can Help With Covid-19 Funeral Costs. Here’s What to Know.
description: The agency has changed its rules to cover deaths that occurred early in the pandemic, when the coronavirus wasn’t always cited on death certificates.
content: Thousands of people who lost members of their family to Covid-19 have received federal financial help for funeral costs, and the government has just changed the rules to help more people qualify.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: A Maryland Summer Starts With Limits on Its Big Attraction: Crab
description: Soaring prices for the catch have led many restaurants to remove favorite dishes from the menu during peak season.
content: Along the Chesapeake Bay shore in Maryland, Bobby Jones has two restaurants known for the magic they work with jumbo lump Chesapeake blue crab. But because of a recent surge in prices, he has had to start the crucial summertime season without his state’s signature dish: crab cakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Coral Murphy Marcos
title: They Didn’t Expect to Retire Early. The Pandemic Changed Their Plans.
description: After years in which Americans worked later in life, the latest economic disruption has driven many out of the work force prematurely.
content: Dee Dee Patten, 57, hadn’t planned to retire early. But when the coronavirus-induced lockdown took hold in 2020 and business dried up at the mechanical repair shop that she and her husband, Dana, owned in Platteville, Colo., they decided to call it quits.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Art World’s Mystique and David Choe’s TV Show: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the journalists who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Wilco’s Jeff Tweedy Wants You to Be Bad at Something. It’s for Your Own Good.
description: A musician’s guide to building a stress-free, nourishing creative practice.
content: Recently, I picked up Jeff Tweedy’s “How to Write One Song.” It was a bit of a lark. content: What better way to understand a people than to look at the books they consumed most — not the ones they were told to read by teachers or parents, but the ones they returned to again and again, with questions about everything from spelling to sex? Our simple dictionaries, cookbooks, almanacs and how-to manuals are the unexamined touchstones for American culture. These dog-eared books for daily life sold tens of millions of copies, ostensibly teaching readers one subject, all while subtly instructing them about their role in society, often offering a single definition of “American.”

content: Despite the urgency of the moment, the mayoral primary on June 22 failed to capture the attention of even a simple majority of New Yorkers, so it was not without irony that the country’s eventual fascination with it was born of a bizarre, bureaucratic error. Treating the primaries as a Netflix series demanding a teaser weeks ahead of showtime, the city’s Board of Elections announced the preliminary results of ranked-choice voting earlier this week, before the final count was due later this month.
